title: Modeling the Difficulty of Saxophone Music
author: Šimon Librický (Institute of Formal and Applied Linguistics, Charles University), Jan Hajič Jr. (Institute of Formal and Applied Linguistics, Charles University), ...
relevance_why: This study presents a novel approach for estimating the difficulty of music for wind instruments, which could inform methods for modeling similar difficulties in audio generation and processing tasks.
background: The research focuses on estimating the difficulty of saxophone music pieces to aid learners in choosing appropriate repertoire and practice strategies.
contribution: This paper introduces a cost-of-traversal model of saxophone performance difficulty, leveraging trill speed data and establishing transition costs between note pairs.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods primarily focused on piano and string instruments with limited applicability to woodwinds, often relying on musician annotations or expert rules.
technical_comparison.novelty: This research utilizes real-world recorded data to estimate transition costs, enabling a more data-driven approach for difficulty estimation applicable to various woodwind instruments.

key_innovation: Combines empirical data collection with a novel cost-of-traversal model, allowing dynamic difficulty assessment based on actual player performance.
real_world_impact: The findings can significantly enhance music education for saxophone players, providing automated tools for difficulty assessment that could improve learner engagement and effectiveness in practice.
limitations: The model requires initial data collection from expert performers and may not accurately reflect the difficulty experienced by less skilled players.

new_terms.cost-of-traversal: **Cost-of-traversal** is a model for evaluating the difficulty of musical passages based on the transitions between different states or note pairs, akin to finding the least expensive route on a graph.

open_sourcing: The code and data used in this research are available at www.github.com/Vobludalib/SaxophoneDifficultyModel/tree/ISMIR2025.
